user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl:
```c
void OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    size_t                        StartPos;
    size_t                        EndPos;
    size_t                        WriteSize;
    OS_console_internal_record_t *console;

    console  = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_console_table, *token);
    StartPos = console->ReadPos;
    EndPos   = console->WritePos;

    OS_BSP_Lock_Impl();

    while (StartPos != EndPos)
    {
        if (StartPos > EndPos)
        {
            /* handle wrap */
            WriteSize = console->BufSize - StartPos;
        }
        else
        {
            WriteSize = EndPos - StartPos;
        }

        OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(&console->BufBase[StartPos], WriteSize);

        StartPos += WriteSize;
        if (StartPos >= console->BufSize)
        {
            /* handle wrap */
            StartPos = 0;
        }
    }

    OS_BSP_Unlock_Impl();

    /* Update the global with the new read location */
    console->ReadPos = StartPos;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ConsoleOutput_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function parameter is modified in the shown code. The sole function parameter is declared as const OS_object_token_t *token and is only dereferenced for read access (used as *token in OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET). There is no assignment to the pointer variable token itself, nor any statement that writes through token. The local variable console is assigned from the object table and its members (e.g. console->ReadPos) are modified — that is allowed because the rule permits modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter (and here console is a local pointer, not the parameter). The helper static inline OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token) only reads token->obj_idx and does not modify the parameter. Therefore there are no fragments that need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 in the provided code.
